oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Tuaregs, reel 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tuaregs; Tuaregs -- Social conditions; Tuaregs -- Economic conditions
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color, 46 min., 2 reels. This is a BBC film made in the mid-1970s. I find this a somewhat curious film: it is very politically alert but it is not clear just what its political sympathies are. Provocative but ambiguous. It was filmed in Niger, apparently with some help from Oxfam. It shows the impact of famine, and efforts to develop by creating agriculture (a project of a European Catholic order), and it also contrasts the impoverished situation of the Tuareg with the luxury of the life of the Europeans working in the uranium mine in the same area. It is most successful in raising questions about different paths of development: successful partly through its own confusion. It seems to be both for and against relief aid, development work that might change Tuareg culture, the Tuareg themselves.
